review_title: It's not perfect, but in the grand scheme, BAC is good place to work
pros: It's one of the largest companies in the world with a huge asset base and more margin for error in the current economic cycle.  With offices throughout the world (though admittedly it's primarily a US bank) and numerous functional positions (e.g. loans: consumer, commercial, large corporate; marketing; legal; tech; etc.), you have the ability to do a variety of things and never leave the firm.
cons: It's one of the largest companies in the world and, like others in that class, comes with its fair share of bureaucracy and politics.  There is also constant change with a reorganization every 18 months or so whether we need it or not.  If you're unnerved by a dynamic, fast paced and changing environment, BAC is not the place for you.  Clearly, an associate's experience will be directly impacted by the people in their organization (i.e. manager, peers, etc.).  You don't have to read this review board for more than five minutes to figure out that some have had better experiences than others, but I would suggest that's no different than most large corporations.  A great boss and team will color your perception of the whole firm and vice versa.  BAC is not a perfect place by any means, but in my experience dealing with other banks and with numerous friends at other firms, it's a well run organization.  Many people have left over the years thinking the grass was greener at Wachovia, JPM, Citi, etc. only to find out that life wasn't so bad at BAC.  Every large institution has their fair share of disfunction.

As a manager, you are expected to work extremely hard with minimal recognition for going above and beyond. This sounds like 'sour grapes', but it's really more 'disappointment' at the opportunities for greatness this organization systemically appears to shun, in favor of short-term incentive-yielding (for the few) metrics. The 'climbers' do well in this environment.   

Advice: Beware of the nice sounding propaganda about culture and values. In my opinion, the work environment is great. The office is filled with a positive vibe- people actually enjoy other co-worker’s company. In addition, there is a clear career path. If you feel as though you are no longer making any progress in your current role/market/line of business, BAC offers an easy to use career site, equipped with a job search engine. The database instantly allows you to view all open positions within the Bank. This makes it easier for anyone who is interested in crossing over to another area of the Bank.
cons: The compensation as compared to other financial firms isn’t as strong (i.e. raises and sign -on bonuses). From my personal experiences, the annual merit increases are lackluster. Given that the Bank is so huge, employees have a larger range of opportunities (i.e. sales, Ibanking, lending, private banking, etc.) and as with every other financial firms, compensation differs from LOB to LOB (not so much geographically, though). I've found that people in the same role across the country have about the same level of pay.
